options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: how economics relates to cities and segregation

I learned about the spatial models of the city, including monocentric city model from Alonso-Muth-Mills, as well as other important models. But most importantly, I got to apply these economic models to practical concerns of urban living today: segregation, transportation, finance, gentrification, violent crime, etc. This course thus became a key driver to learn about the problems facing the city through an economic lens.

I learned a useful overview of core urban development models including the alonso-muth-mills model of urban development, and I also learned some useful frameworks for thinking about why cities end up the way they do.
So many interesting perspectives on urban issues, very current issues in that field, and SO MUCH MORE. I learned a ton in this class and am so grateful.
I learned more about the economic models for understanding cities.

Really interesting course that covered material not covered by almost any other economics course. A very thoughtful balance of theory and application. Definitely one of the most useful economics courses I've taken.
We learned an overview of the basic theories and models surrounding urban economics, taking a look at various cities as case studies
everything from poverty, to pollution, to modes of transportation
Models describing spatial view of cities; what urban cities are like and why

I learned basic details about urban economics, including models of urban density, inter-urban rent and wage premia, segregation, gentrification, and more. The class had some focus on math, but mainly it was a conceptually-driven class.
I learned a lot about the economic models of space, urbanization and development.

I learn so much about the most recent researches on the topics of urban economics, such as agglomeration and urban density. I enjoy learning presentation skills that summarize key findings and author critiques.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strength: Sun is such an amazing person who is just so so so supportive of her students. 
Weakness: I think some of the content could have been elaborated better through a handout that clarified the key models that we are expected to know. I partially blame it on zoom, but it was a bit difficult to follow along in some parts of the lecture.
I wish we worked more on the final paper in class? I thought it was fun that we could dive deep into whatever we want.

Strengths: I really appreciated the opportunity to work with a group on problem sets and also on student presentations, as it was lovely to be able to work with and hear from my peers and engage in discussion and collaboration about the most recent papers in the urban economics field. The major strength of this course is Sun herself. She is such a wonderful professor, with engaging lectures and anecdotes, and is so willing to host office hours and help students craft paper proposals that make sense and are of interest to them. Not only is the course content so wonderful and interesting, but she is herself a big reason why this course was a success.

Strengths: Sun is such a warm and enthusiastic professor. She does a good job of engaging the class even on an online format, and she was always very open to feedback and flexible in terms of scheduling assignments. She really seemed to care about each one of us!

Weaknesses: I feel like I could have learned more if we didn't have student presentations once a week. The presentations were interesting but based mostly off of memorizing papers that we would read for class, so I didn't feel like I learned anything in depth, just a lot of different things at a shallow level.
Professor Sun is the best human on this earth.
Prof Sun is a great teacher! She really does a superb job of being there for us to ensure that we understand the material. Her office hours are convenient and the lectures are well formated!

The biggest strength is that Sun is by far the most caring, thoughtful professor I've had at Yale. Aside from the unparalleled effort she puts in, she is also an extremely knowledgable and skilled professor. The material is really interesting as well. No weaknesses come to mind.
The readings and lectures were extremely well structured and interesting, covering a wide breadth of topics that always made the course engaging
BEST CLASS EVER. BEST PROFESSOR EVER. Sun is incredible. Cannot be improved.

I liked how engaging the professor was; she even made the effort to cold call on us -- which I liked; I also liked hearing student presentations on the papers

In terms of assignments, the group partnerships seemed to not work very well. I'd prefer, because of that, to possibly split pset 1 into multiple psets or just encourage working alone.

The biggest strength of the class was the professor's clear enthusiasm for the subject matter and effort to make the class enjoyable for all of us. I also thought that some of the papers we read were extremely interesting and insightful.

I thought the biggest weakness of the class was that we didn't really go in depth enough. The class often focused on details that were relatively obvious, rather than economic models. There were two problem sets that went more in depth, but I felt relatively unprepared for them.
I think this class would be better if it was either a) about a specific region or b)about a specific model. It was hard to learn such a wide breadth of topics.

Strengths- prof Sun, the interactive nature of the class, the content! 

Weaknesses- it seemed a little disorganised at time

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Virtual seminars in general are just hard so I wish we had this class in person to be more engaged

Successes: Interaction and discussion -- Sun would always ask us questions about our own experiences and intuitions, which made the class feel engaging. 

Could be improved: utilizing the chat option more so that everyone has a chance to test their understanding. I think some people were probably pretty checked out.

Somehow Professor Sun facilitated SUCH a positive zoom environment. She made an effort to keep every student engaged, and constantly gave feedback. She checked in on us as a friend, and treated all students with respect, and care.
Sun succeeded at everything

The professor tried to make this into an interactive class, which sometimes worked well, but I felt that the class was probably too big for it to be truly interactive. In addition, there were a lot of student presentations, which often were interactive but only at the very end, which made the class less engaging. I think in the future, it could be better to have more of a discussion format rather than lectures for the student presentations, and the size of the class could potentially be limited.
NA

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would full-heartedly recommend this course to another student. Sun is the best professor I have met at Yale. She is just so supportive and kind-hearted that it was such a pleasure to have been her student. She is always open to meet and communicates thoroughly with the students. Furthermore, she really cares a lot about each individual student and the subject matter of the class. I think everyone should take this class to interact with Sun, especially for those who feel as if they have not found a Yale professor that cares about their well-being.
Yes! Especially if they are interested in cities

Without a doubt, I would recommend this course to another student who is interested in economics and how it applies to the city & built urban environment. This course gives you a toolkit by which you can explore a specific topic of interest while also learning from peers and the instructor. This is one of my favorite courses I have taken at Yale simply because the classroom environment was so supportive, intellectually stimulating, and fun to be in, even though it was over Zoom. Moreover, Sun is incredibly flexible and kind, making sure that each student is supported and feels welcome in the classroom. There are very few professors like her at Yale who are as approachable and good mentors as she is.

I would recommend this course to students who are interested in more of the urban studies side than the economics side of city planning. I liked that we departed often from usual economic assumptions and focused on anecdotal and historical cases, but if you're looking for a rigorous economics course, this might not be it.
YES YES YES. TAKE IT. BEST CLASS AND PROFESSOR AT YALE. ABSOLUTE GEM. NOT ONLY DID I LEARN SO MUCH, but I retained everything.
Yes, wholeheartedly
Definitely recommend! wonderful professor!
Definitely take this class if you are interested in learning more about how economists view cities!
Absolutely. This would be #1 on my list of recommendations - truly an amazing course.
Yes, the course is great for anyone who is interested in learning about urban spaces and how they are structured!
ABSOLUTELY

I'd recommend this course to a person with a variety of interests: education, welfare, inequality, etc. The course does a good job at allowing students to independently research these topics and possibly write on or present it.

I would recommend it to somebody who knows they are interested in the economics of cities. I was mainly taking it to learn more about urban economics, and it wasn't a great class for me. Though there were parts of the class that were interesting, I'm not sure I came out with all that much more knowledge. I think a lot of this was because it became hard for me to focus in class, more so than other classes, and I didn't absorb as much as I could have.
Yes
I highly recommend the course to students who are interested in urban policies and want to see how empirical models are applied to urban issues.
Yes it was really interesting and a cool perspective on economics!

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: A small lecture that ends up being pretty discussion-based, with weekly student-led presentations/discussions
Great, interactive seminar. The best seminar Ive taken at Yale with the best professor I could ever ask for.

recorded lecture
live virtual lecture
None
recorded lecture
The class consisted of virtual lectures once a week, as well as student-given lectures once a week.
NA
